    similar-work

    similar-work.Rmd

    Motivation

    This vignette covers similar functions/packages that compare two datasets to each other.

    Packages

    Our package

    library(dfdiffs)

    Similar packages

    library(janitor) # compare_df_cols
library(arsenal) # comparedf
library(diffdf)  # diffdf
library(testthat) # expect_equal
library(vetr) # alike

    Data

    We’ll be using the data in this package to cover similar packages::functions().

    New data

    To check new data, we’re going to use T1Data and T2Data. The create_new_data() function shows us the ‘new data’ (i.e. what is here now that wasn’t here before?)

    We can check this against the NewData dataset (which should match the output from create_new_data())

    T1Data <- dfdiffs::T1Data
T2Data <- dfdiffs::T2Data
create_new_data(newdf = T2Data, olddf = T1Data)
#> Error in create_new_data(newdf = T2Data, olddf = T1Data): unused arguments (newdf = T2Data, olddf = T1Data)
    NewData <- dfdiffs::NewData
NewData
#> # A tibble: 3 × 7
#>   subject record start_date mid_date   end_date   text_var            factor_var
#>   <chr>   <chr>  <date>     <date>     <date>     <chr>               <chr>     
#> 1 D       5      2022-04-04 2022-04-13 2022-04-22 Four hours of stea… associate 
#> 2 B       4      2022-04-02 2022-04-14 2022-04-20 The hogs were fed … encourage 
#> 3 A       2      2022-04-04 2022-04-15 2022-04-21 The box was thrown… pension

    Deleted data

    To test for the deleted data, we use the CompleteData, IncompleteData, and DeletedData. CompleteData represents a ‘complete’ set of data, and IncompleteData is a dataset with rows removed from CompleteData.

    When we run the create_deleted_data(), we check for the deleted rows between IncompleteData and CompleteData.

    CompleteData <- dfdiffs::CompleteData
IncompleteData <- dfdiffs::IncompleteData
create_deleted_data(newdf = IncompleteData, olddf = CompleteData)
#> Error in create_deleted_data(newdf = IncompleteData, olddf = CompleteData): unused arguments (newdf = IncompleteData, olddf = CompleteData)

    This is identical to the data stored in DeletedData

    DeletedData <- dfdiffs::DeletedData
DeletedData
#> # A tibble: 4 × 7
#>   subject record start_date mid_date   end_date   text_var            factor_var
#>   <chr>    <int> <date>     <date>     <date>     <chr>               <chr>     
#> 1 A            2 2021-12-28 2022-01-27 2022-02-26 Mark the spot with… state     
#> 2 B            3 2021-12-26 2022-01-25 2022-02-24 A blue crane is a … shut      
#> 3 C            1 2021-12-30 2022-01-29 2022-02-28 It's easy to tell … grant     
#> 4 D            1 2021-12-27 2022-01-26 2022-02-25 The sky that morni… tape

    Modified Data

    To check for changes between two datasets, we uses the InitialData and ChangedData.

    InitialData <- dfdiffs::InitialData
ChangedData <- dfdiffs::ChangedData
mods <- create_modified_data(
  newdf = ChangedData, 
  olddf = InitialData)
#> Error in create_modified_data(newdf = ChangedData, olddf = InitialData): unused arguments (newdf = ChangedData, olddf = InitialData)

    The changes by variable are stored in diffs_byvar.

    mods$diffs_byvar
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'mods' not found

    The changes by row are stored in diffs.

    mods$diffs
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'mods' not found

    Lahman datasets

    We will also import two master datasets from the Lahman baseball package.

    master15 <- readxl::read_excel(
  path = "../inst/extdata/xlsx/lahman_compare.xlsx", 
  sheet = "master-2015")
master20 <- readxl::read_excel(
  path = "../inst/extdata/xlsx/lahman_compare.xlsx", 
  sheet = "master-2020")

    janitor::compare_df_cols_same()

    The compare_df_cols_same() function from janitor compares two datasets and “indicates if they will successfully bind together by rows.”

    compare_df_cols_same(T1Data, T2Data, strict_description = FALSE)
#> [1] TRUE
compare_df_cols_same(CompleteData, IncompleteData, strict_description = FALSE)
#> [1] TRUE
compare_df_cols_same(InitialData, ChangedData, strict_description = FALSE)
#> [1] TRUE

    All of our test datasets meet this condition, but this could be used as a step in one our create_ functions (to see if they can be successfully bound together).

    diffdf::diffdf()

    The diffdf() function is very similar to arsenal::comparedf()

    If we run the function without assigning the output to an object, we see the following:

    diffdf::diffdf(base = InitialData , compare = ChangedData)
#> Differences found between the objects!
#> 
#> A summary is given below.
#> 
#> Not all Values Compared Equal
#> All rows are shown in table below
#> 
#>   =================================
#>      Variable    No of Differences 
#>   ---------------------------------
#>    text_value_a          2         
#>    text_value_b          1         
#>    updated_date          5         
#>    entered_date          5         
#>   ---------------------------------
#> 
#> 
#> All rows are shown in table below
#> 
#>   ===============================================================
#>      VARIABLE    ..ROWNUMBER..        BASE           COMPARE     
#>   ---------------------------------------------------------------
#>    text_value_a        1        Issue unresolved  Issue resolved 
#>    text_value_a        2        Issue unresolved  Issue resolved 
#>   ---------------------------------------------------------------
#> 
#> 
#> All rows are shown in table below
#> 
#>   ============================================================================
#>      VARIABLE    ..ROWNUMBER..     BASE                  COMPARE              
#>   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#>    text_value_b        4        Joint pain  Joint pain, stiffness and swel... 
#>   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> 
#> 
#> All rows are shown in table below
#> 
#>   =====================================================
#>      VARIABLE    ..ROWNUMBER..     BASE      COMPARE   
#>   -----------------------------------------------------
#>    updated_date        1        2021-09-29  2021-10-03 
#>    updated_date        2        2021-10-03  2021-11-27 
#>    updated_date        3        2021-09-02  2021-10-20 
#>    updated_date        4        2021-10-03  2021-10-13 
#>    updated_date        5        2021-09-20  2021-10-14 
#>   -----------------------------------------------------
#> 
#> 
#> All rows are shown in table below
#> 
#>   =====================================================
#>      VARIABLE    ..ROWNUMBER..     BASE      COMPARE   
#>   -----------------------------------------------------
#>    entered_date        1        2021-09-29  2021-11-30 
#>    entered_date        2        2021-10-29  2021-11-30 
#>    entered_date        3        2021-08-18  2021-11-21 
#>    entered_date        4        2021-10-03  2021-11-11 
#>    entered_date        5        2021-10-20  2021-11-16 
#>   -----------------------------------------------------

    If we assign the output to an object (diffdf_output), we can check it’s structure:

    # assign to an output
diffdf_output <- diffdf::diffdf(base = InitialData , compare = ChangedData)
str(diffdf_output)
#> List of 5
#>  $ NumDiff             : issue [4 × 2] (S3: issue/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>   ..$ Variable         : chr [1:4] "text_value_a" "text_value_b" "updated_date" "entered_date"
#>   ..$ No of Differences: Named int [1:4] 2 1 5 5
#>   .. ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:4] "text_value_a" "text_value_b" "updated_date" "entered_date"
#>   ..- attr(*, "message")= chr "Not all Values Compared Equal"
#>  $ VarDiff_text_value_a: issue [2 × 4] (S3: issue/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>   ..$ VARIABLE     : chr [1:2] "text_value_a" "text_value_a"
#>   ..$ ..ROWNUMBER..: int [1:2] 1 2
#>   ..$ BASE         : chr [1:2] "Issue unresolved" "Issue unresolved"
#>   ..$ COMPARE      : chr [1:2] "Issue resolved" "Issue resolved"
#>   ..- attr(*, "message")= chr ""
#>  $ VarDiff_text_value_b: issue [1 × 4] (S3: issue/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>   ..$ VARIABLE     : chr "text_value_b"
#>   ..$ ..ROWNUMBER..: int 4
#>   ..$ BASE         : chr "Joint pain"
#>   ..$ COMPARE      : chr "Joint pain, stiffness and swelling"
#>   ..- attr(*, "message")= chr ""
#>  $ VarDiff_updated_date: issue [5 × 4] (S3: issue/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>   ..$ VARIABLE     : chr [1:5] "updated_date" "updated_date" "updated_date" "updated_date" ...
#>   ..$ ..ROWNUMBER..: int [1:5] 1 2 3 4 5
#>   ..$ BASE         : Date[1:5], format: "2021-09-29" "2021-10-03" ...
#>   ..$ COMPARE      : Date[1:5], format: "2021-10-03" "2021-11-27" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "message")= chr ""
#>  $ VarDiff_entered_date: issue [5 × 4] (S3: issue/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>   ..$ VARIABLE     : chr [1:5] "entered_date" "entered_date" "entered_date" "entered_date" ...
#>   ..$ ..ROWNUMBER..: int [1:5] 1 2 3 4 5
#>   ..$ BASE         : Date[1:5], format: "2021-09-29" "2021-10-29" ...
#>   ..$ COMPARE      : Date[1:5], format: "2021-11-30" "2021-11-30" ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "message")= chr ""
#>  - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "diffdf" "list"
#>  - attr(*, "keys")=List of 2
#>   ..$ value     : chr "..ROWNUMBER.."
#>   ..$ is_derived: logi TRUE

    This list contains objects named according to NumDiff and VarDiff. We will test this with the larger master datasets.

    testthat::expect_equal()

    This works, but returns the result as an error.

    testthat::expect_equal(object = InitialData, expected = ChangedData)
#> Error: `InitialData` not equal to `ChangedData`.
#> Component "text_value_a": 2 string mismatches
#> Component "text_value_b": 1 string mismatch
#> Component "updated_date": Mean relative difference: 0.001492585
#> Component "entered_date": Mean relative difference: 0.002698184
    testthat::expect_equal(object = T1Data, expected = T2Data)
#> Error: `T1Data` not equal to `T2Data`.
#> Attributes: < Component "row.names": Numeric: lengths (6, 9) differ >
#> Component "subject": Lengths (6, 9) differ (string compare on first 6)
#> Component "subject": 5 string mismatches
#> Component "record": Numeric: lengths (6, 9) differ
#> Component "start_date": Numeric: lengths (6, 9) differ
#> Component "mid_date": Numeric: lengths (6, 9) differ
#> Component "end_date": Numeric: lengths (6, 9) differ
#> Component "text_var": Lengths (6, 9) differ (string compare on first 6)
#> Component "text_var": 5 string mismatches
#> ...

    vetr::alike() 

    vetr::alike(target = InitialData, current = ChangedData)
#> [1] TRUE
